articles.title: Grammaire tchÃ¨que : les bases essentielles pour dÃ©butants
articles.content:
import VocabCard from '@components/VocabCard.astro';
import CultureTip from '@components/CultureTip.astro';
import PhraseOfDay from '@components/PhraseOfDay.astro';
import CTA from '@components/CTA.astro';

La grammaire tchÃ¨que a 7 cas et 3 genres, ce qui peut sembler intimidant. Mais avec les bonnes bases, vous progresserez rapidement !

<PhraseOfDay
  word="Miluji tÄ›"
  translation="Je t'aime"
  pronunciation="MI-lou-yi tyÃ©"
  context="Â« TÄ› Â» est l'accusatif de Â« ty Â» (tu) - votre premiÃ¨re leÃ§on de cas !"
/>

## Les genres en tchÃ¨que

Le tchÃ¨que a trois genres : masculin, fÃ©minin et neutre.

### Comment reconnaÃ®tre le genre ?

<VocabCard
  word="Masculin : consonne finale"
  translation="MuÅ¾ (homme), hrad (chÃ¢teau), stÅ¯l (table)"
  pronunciation="mouj, hrad, stoul"
  example="La plupart des mots finissant par une consonne sont masculins"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="FÃ©minin : -a ou -e final"
  translation="Å½ena (femme), rÅ¯Å¾e (rose), kniha (livre)"
  pronunciation="JÃ‰-na, ROU-jÃ©, KNI-ha"
  example="Les mots en -a ou -e sont gÃ©nÃ©ralement fÃ©minins"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Neutre : -o ou -Ã­ final"
  translation="MÄ›sto (ville), moÅ™e (mer), stavenÃ­ (bÃ¢timent)"
  pronunciation="MNYES-to, MO-rjÃ©, sta-VYÃ‰-nii"
  example="Les mots en -o ou -Ã­ sont gÃ©nÃ©ralement neutres"
/>

<CultureTip title="Masculin animÃ© vs inanimÃ©" flag="ğŸ‡¨ğŸ‡¿">
Le tchÃ¨que distingue aussi les noms masculins animÃ©s (Ãªtres vivants) des inanimÃ©s (objets). Cela affecte la dÃ©clinaison. Â« MuÅ¾ Â» (homme) et Â« pes Â» (chien) sont animÃ©s, Â« stÅ¯l Â» (table) est inanimÃ©.
</CultureTip>

## Le systÃ¨me des cas

Le tchÃ¨que utilise 7 cas qui changent la terminaison des mots.

### Les 7 cas tchÃ¨ques

| Cas | Question | Usage | Exemple avec Â« Å¾ena Â» |
|-----|----------|-------|----------------------|
| **Nominatif** | Kdo? Co? | Sujet | Å½ena Äte (La femme lit) |
| **GÃ©nitif** | Koho? ÄŒeho? | Possession | Kniha Å¾eny (Le livre de la femme) |
| **Datif** | Komu? ÄŒemu? | Attribution | DÃ¡vÃ¡m Å¾enÄ› (Je donne Ã  la femme) |
| **Accusatif** | Koho? Co? | COD | VidÃ­m Å¾enu (Je vois la femme) |
| **Vocatif** | - | Interpellation | Å½eno! (Femme !) |
| **Locatif** | O kom? O Äem? | Lieu, sujet | O Å¾enÄ› (Ã€ propos de la femme) |
| **Instrumental** | S kÃ½m? ÄŒÃ­m? | Moyen | Se Å¾enou (Avec la femme) |

<VocabCard
  word="LÃ¡ska (amour) - dÃ©clinaison"
  translation="Nom. lÃ¡ska, GÃ©n. lÃ¡sky, Dat. lÃ¡sce, Acc. lÃ¡sku"
  pronunciation="LAAS-ka"
  example="Moje lÃ¡ska"
/>

<CultureTip title="Commencez petit !" flag="ğŸ‡¨ğŸ‡¿">
N'essayez pas d'apprendre tous les cas d'un coup. Commencez par le nominatif (sujet) et l'accusatif (COD) - ce sont les plus utiles au quotidien. Les autres viendront naturellement avec la pratique.
</CultureTip>

## Conjugaison des verbes

### Le prÃ©sent

Les verbes tchÃ¨ques se conjuguent selon la personne.

<VocabCard
  word="Milovat (aimer)"
  translation="Je t'aime = Miluji tÄ›"
  pronunciation="MI-lo-vat"
  example="Verbe du premier groupe"
/>

| Personne | Milovat (aimer) | Mluvit (parler) |
|----------|-----------------|-----------------|
| JÃ¡ (je) | miluji | mluvÃ­m |
| Ty (tu) | milujeÅ¡ | mluvÃ­Å¡ |
| On/Ona (il/elle) | miluje | mluvÃ­ |
| My (nous) | milujeme | mluvÃ­me |
| Vy (vous) | milujete | mluvÃ­te |
| Oni (ils/elles) | milujÃ­ | mluvÃ­ |

<VocabCard
  word="BÃ½t (Ãªtre)"
  translation="Je suis = Jsem"
  pronunciation="biit / ysÃ©m"
  example="Verbe irrÃ©gulier essentiel"
/>

| Personne | BÃ½t (Ãªtre) |
|----------|------------|
| JÃ¡ | jsem |
| Ty | jsi |
| On/Ona | je |
| My | jsme |
| Vy | jste |
| Oni | jsou |

### Le passÃ©

Le passÃ© tchÃ¨que utilise le participe passÃ© + l'auxiliaire Â« bÃ½t Â».

<VocabCard
  word="PassÃ© masculin : -l"
  translation="Miloval jsem (J'ai aimÃ© - homme)"
  pronunciation="MI-lo-val ysÃ©m"
  example="Participe en -l + jsem"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="PassÃ© fÃ©minin : -la"
  translation="Milovala jsem (J'ai aimÃ© - femme)"
  pronunciation="MI-lo-va-la ysÃ©m"
  example="Participe en -la + jsem"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="PassÃ© pluriel : -li/-ly"
  translation="Milovali jsme (Nous avons aimÃ©)"
  pronunciation="MI-lo-va-li ys-mÃ©"
  example="Participe en -li + jsme"
/>

<CultureTip title="Genre au passÃ©" flag="ğŸ‡¨ğŸ‡¿">
Comme en russe, le passÃ© tchÃ¨que s'accorde avec le sujet en genre. Si vous Ãªtes un homme, dites Â« Byl jsem Â» (J'Ã©tais). Si vous Ãªtes une femme, dites Â« Byla jsem Â». Votre partenaire apprÃ©ciera que vous fassiez l'effort !
</CultureTip>

## Les pronoms personnels

| FranÃ§ais | TchÃ¨que | Prononciation |
|----------|---------|---------------|
| Je | JÃ¡ | yaa |
| Tu | Ty | ti |
| Il | On | on |
| Elle | Ona | O-na |
| Nous | My | mi |
| Vous | Vy | vi |
| Ils/Elles | Oni/Ony | O-ni/O-ni |

<VocabCard
  word="Ty vs Vy"
  translation="Tu (informel) vs Vous (formel)"
  pronunciation="ti / vi"
  example="Utilisez Vy avec la famille de votre partenaire au dÃ©but"
/>

## Les adjectifs

Les adjectifs s'accordent en genre, nombre et cas.

<VocabCard
  word="KrÃ¡snÃ½ / KrÃ¡snÃ¡ / KrÃ¡snÃ©"
  translation="Beau / Belle / Beau (neutre)"
  pronunciation="KRAAS-nii / KRAAS-naa / KRAAS-nÃ©"
  example="KrÃ¡snÃ¡ Å¾ena"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="MilÃ½ / MilÃ¡ / MilÃ©"
  translation="Cher / ChÃ¨re / Cher (neutre)"
  pronunciation="MI-lii / MI-laa / MI-lÃ©"
  example="MilÃ¡"
/>

## La nÃ©gation

<VocabCard
  word="Ne-"
  translation="PrÃ©fixe de nÃ©gation"
  pronunciation="nÃ©"
  example="NerozumÃ­m"
/>

En tchÃ¨que, on ajoute Â« ne- Â» devant le verbe :

| Affirmatif | NÃ©gatif |
|------------|---------|
| Miluji (J'aime) | Nemiluji (Je n'aime pas) |
| RozumÃ­m (Je comprends) | NerozumÃ­m (Je ne comprends pas) |
| VÃ­m (Je sais) | NevÃ­m (Je ne sais pas) |

## Questions essentielles

<VocabCard
  word="Co?"
  translation="Quoi ?"
  pronunciation="tso"
  example="Co dÄ›lÃ¡Å¡?"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Kdo?"
  translation="Qui ?"
  pronunciation="gdo"
  example="Kdo to je?"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Kde?"
  translation="OÃ¹ ?"
  pronunciation="gdÃ©"
  example="Kde jsi?"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="ProÄ?"
  translation="Pourquoi ?"
  pronunciation="protch"
  example="ProÄ jsi smutnÃ½?"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Jak?"
  translation="Comment ?"
  pronunciation="yak"
  example="Jak se mÃ¡Å¡?"
/>

## Phrases pratiques

<VocabCard
  word="Miluji tÄ›"
  translation="Je t'aime"
  pronunciation="MI-lou-yi tyÃ©"
  example="tÄ›"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Jsi moje lÃ¡ska"
  translation="Tu es mon amour"
  pronunciation="ysi MO-yÃ© LAAS-ka"
  example="moje"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Chci bÃ½t s tebou"
  translation="Je veux Ãªtre avec toi"
  pronunciation="khtsi biit s TÃ‰-bou"
  example="tebou"
/>

## Conseils pour progresser

1. **Apprenez les phrases** - Pas seulement les rÃ¨gles
2. **Focalisez-vous sur l'accusatif** - Le cas le plus utile
3. **Ã‰coutez et rÃ©pÃ©tez** - L'oreille s'habitue
4. **Faites des erreurs** - C'est normal et nÃ©cessaire
5. **Pratiquez avec votre partenaire** - La meilleure motivation !

<CTA />

articles.title: Polish Phone Calls: Answer Like a Local
articles.content:
import VocabCard from '@components/VocabCard.astro';
import ConjugationTable from '@components/ConjugationTable.astro';
import CultureTip from '@components/CultureTip.astro';
import PhraseOfDay from '@components/PhraseOfDay.astro';
import CTA from '@components/CTA.astro';

Phone conversations in Polish can feel intimidating, but they're an essential skill for couples visiting Poland or communicating with Polish-speaking family. Without visual cues, you'll rely entirely on listening skills and proper telephone etiquette.

<PhraseOfDay
  polish="SÅ‚ucham?"
  english="Hello? (literally: I'm listening)"
  pronunciation="SWOO-ham"
  context="The most common way to answer the phone in Poland - polite and professional."
/>

## How Polish People Answer the Phone

Unlike English speakers who say "Hello," Polish speakers have several distinct ways to answer:

### Formal Answering

**SÅ‚ucham?** (I'm listening?) is the gold standard. It's polite, professional, and works in any situation. The question mark indicates you're ready to hear what the caller has to say.

<VocabCard
  polish="SÅ‚ucham?"
  english="Hello? / I'm listening?"
  pronunciation="SWOO-ham"
  example="SÅ‚ucham? Kto mÃ³wi?"
/>

### Casual Family Answering

**Tak?** (Yes?) is more casual and typically used with family or close friends. It's direct and informal.

**Halo?** (Hello?) borrowed from other languages, is becoming more common among younger Poles.

### Business Phone Etiquette

When answering for a business or formally:

**"DzieÅ„ dobry, sÅ‚ucham"** (Good day, I'm listening) - professional morning greeting
**"Dobry wieczÃ³r, sÅ‚ucham"** (Good evening, I'm listening) - professional evening greeting

<CultureTip title="Polish Phone Etiquette">
Poles value directness in phone calls. Don't spend too much time on pleasantries - state your purpose clearly and politely.
</CultureTip>

## Making Phone Calls: Essential Openers

When you're the one calling, start with a proper greeting and identify yourself:

### Calling Friends or Family

**"CzeÅ›Ä‡, tu [your name]"** (Hi, this is [your name])
**"Hej, mÃ³wi [your name]"** (Hey, [your name] speaking)

### Formal Calls

**"DzieÅ„ dobry, nazywam siÄ™ [your name]"** (Good day, my name is [your name])
**"Dobry wieczÃ³r, tu [your name] z [company/organization]"** (Good evening, this is [your name] from [company/organization])

<VocabCard
  polish="Nazywam siÄ™"
  english="My name is"
  pronunciation="na-ZY-vam sheh"
  example="DzieÅ„ dobry, nazywam siÄ™ Anna Kowalska."
/>

## Key Phone Conversation Verbs

<ConjugationTable
  verb="MÃ³wiÄ‡"
  meaning="to speak"
  conjugations={[
    { person: "I", polish: "mÃ³wiÄ™", english: "I speak" },
    { person: "You (informal)", polish: "mÃ³wisz", english: "you speak" },
    { person: "He/She", polish: "mÃ³wi", english: "he/she speaks" },
    { person: "We", polish: "mÃ³wimy", english: "we speak" },
    { person: "You (plural)", polish: "mÃ³wicie", english: "you all speak" },
    { person: "They", polish: "mÃ³wiÄ…", english: "they speak" }
  ]}
/>

## Essential Phone Phrases

### Asking to Speak with Someone

| Polish | English | Pronunciation |
|---|---|---|
| Czy mogÄ™ rozmawiaÄ‡ z...? | Can I speak with...? | chih MO-geh roz-ma-VYACH z |
| Czy jest [name]? | Is [name] there? | chih yest |
| PoproszÄ™ [name] | I'd like [name] please | po-PRO-sheh |

### When Someone Isn't Available

**"Nie ma go/jej"** (He/She isn't here)
**"Jest zajÄ™ty/zajÄ™ta"** (He/She is busy)
**"WyszedÅ‚/WyszÅ‚a"** (He/She went out)

<VocabCard
  polish="Czy mogÄ™ zostawiÄ‡ wiadomoÅ›Ä‡?"
  english="Can I leave a message?"
  pronunciation="chih MO-geh zo-STA-veech vya-do-MOSHCH"
  example="Nie ma go? Czy mogÄ™ zostawiÄ‡ wiadomoÅ›Ä‡?"
/>

### Taking Messages

**"Czy chce Pan/Pani zostawiÄ‡ wiadomoÅ›Ä‡?"** (Would you like to leave a message? - formal)
**"CoÅ› przekaÅ¼esz?"** (Will you pass something along? - informal)
**"Powiem mu/jej"** (I'll tell him/her)

## Romantic Phone Calls

When calling your Polish partner, these phrases add sweetness:

**"Kochanie, to ja"** (Darling, it's me)
**"TÄ™skniÄ™ za tobÄ…"** (I miss you)
**"DzwoniÄ™, bo..."** (I'm calling because...)
**"Kiedy siÄ™ zobaczymy?"** (When will we see each other?)

## Ending Phone Calls Politely

### Casual Endings

**"Na razie!"** (See you later!)
**"CzeÅ›Ä‡!"** (Bye!)
**"Do usÅ‚yszenia!"** (Talk to you later!)

### Formal Endings

**"Do widzenia"** (Goodbye)
**"MiÅ‚ego dnia"** (Have a nice day)
**"DziÄ™kujÄ™ za rozmowÄ™"** (Thank you for the conversation)

<VocabCard
  polish="Do usÅ‚yszenia"
  english="Talk to you later / Until we hear each other again"
  pronunciation="do oos-WI-she-nya"
  example="Dobrze, do usÅ‚yszenia wieczorem!"
/>

## Dealing with Connection Problems

**"Nie sÅ‚yszÄ™"** (I can't hear)
**"Å¹le sÅ‚ychaÄ‡"** (The connection is bad)
**"ProszÄ™ mÃ³wiÄ‡ gÅ‚oÅ›niej"** (Please speak louder)
**"RozÅ‚Ä…czamy siÄ™"** (We're getting disconnected)
**"ZadzwoniÄ™ ponownie"** (I'll call again)

## Common Phone Call Scenarios

### Calling a Restaurant

**"DzieÅ„ dobry, chciaÅ‚bym zarezerwowaÄ‡ stolik"** (Good day, I'd like to reserve a table)
**"Na ile osÃ³b?"** (For how many people?)
**"Na ktÃ³rÄ… godzinÄ™?"** (For what time?)

### Calling for Information

**"Przepraszam, czy mogÄ™ zapytaÄ‡ o...?"** (Excuse me, can I ask about...?)
**"Jakie sÄ… godziny otwarcia?"** (What are the opening hours?)
**"Ile to kosztuje?"** (How much does it cost?)

<CultureTip title="Phone Number Format">
Polish phone numbers are typically said digit by digit, not in groups. The number 123-456-789 would be "jeden, dwa, trzy, cztery, piÄ™Ä‡, szeÅ›Ä‡, siedem, osiem, dziewiÄ™Ä‡."
</CultureTip>

## Emergency Calls

While hopefully you'll never need these, it's important to know:

**"To nagÅ‚y wypadek"** (This is an emergency)
**"PotrzebujÄ™ pomocy"** (I need help)
**"ProszÄ™ przysÅ‚aÄ‡ karetkÄ™"** (Please send an ambulance)

## Practice Tips for Couples

1. **Role Play Together**: Take turns being the caller and the person answering
2. **Record Conversations**: Practice and listen back to improve pronunciation
3. **Start Simple**: Begin with basic scenarios before moving to complex business calls
4. **Use Polish Names**: Practice with typical Polish names like Anna, Piotr, or Katarzyna

> Pro tip: Polish phone conversations tend to be more direct than English ones. Don't be offended by the brevity - it's cultural efficiency, not rudeness!

## Building Confidence

Phone calls in a foreign language are challenging because you can't rely on body language or facial expressions. Start with familiar people who speak slowly and clearly. As your confidence grows, you'll find Polish phone conversations become second nature.

Remember, even native speakers sometimes ask **"MoÅ¼esz powtÃ³rzyÄ‡?"** (Can you repeat that?) during phone calls. Don't be afraid to ask for clarification!


<CTA
  text="Practice phone conversations with interactive lessons"
  buttonText="Start Learning"
/>

articles.title: SeznÃ¡menÃ­ s partnerovou rodinou v tureÄtinÄ›: ZÃ­skejte si jejich srdce sprÃ¡vnÃ½mi frÃ¡zemi
articles.content:
import VocabCard from '@components/VocabCard.astro';
import CultureTip from '@components/CultureTip.astro';
import PhraseOfDay from '@components/PhraseOfDay.astro';
import CTA from '@components/CTA.astro';

PrvnÃ­ setkÃ¡nÃ­ s rodinou vaÅ¡eho tureckÃ©ho partnera mÅ¯Å¾e bÃ½t nervy drÃ¡sajÃ­cÃ­ zÃ¡Å¾itek. Ale nebojte se! S tÄ›mito frÃ¡zemi zÃ­skÃ¡te jejich srdce a ukÃ¡Å¾ete, Å¾e si vÃ¡Å¾Ã­te jejich kultury. SprÃ¡vnÃ¡ slovnÃ­ zÃ¡soba vÃ¡m pomÅ¯Å¾e vytvoÅ™it teplÃ© spojenÃ­, kterÃ© pÅ™ekonÃ¡ jazykovou bariÃ©ru.

<PhraseOfDay
  word="Ã‡ok memnun oldum"
  translation="Velmi mÄ› tÄ›Å¡Ã­"
  pronunciation="tchoch mem-nun ol-dum"
  context="NejdÅ¯leÅ¾itÄ›jÅ¡Ã­ frÃ¡ze pÅ™i prvnÃ­m setkÃ¡nÃ­ - pouÅ¾ijte ji pÅ™i podÃ¡nÃ­ ruky"
/>

## PÅ™Ã­prava pÅ™ed nÃ¡vÅ¡tÄ›vou

NeÅ¾ vkroÄÃ­te do domu vaÅ¡eho partnera, je dÅ¯leÅ¾itÃ© znÃ¡s nÄ›kolik zÃ¡kladnÃ­ch pravidel. TureckÃ¡ kultura klade velkÃ½ dÅ¯raz na Ãºctu k starÅ¡Ã­m a pohostinnost. Pokud si nejste jisti, jak sprÃ¡vnÄ› [oslovit partnerovy rodiÄe](/learn/cs/tr/turkish-greetings-and-farewells/), zaÄnÄ›te formÃ¡lnÄ›.

<VocabCard
  word="Aile"
  translation="Rodina"
  pronunciation="aj-le"
  example="Aileniz Ã§ok sÄ±cakkanlÄ±."
/>

<CultureTip flag="ğŸ‡¹ğŸ‡·" title="OdstraÅˆte boty">
V tureckÃ½ch domÃ¡cnostech se obvykle pÅ™i vstupu zouvÃ¡. PoÄkejte, aÅ¾ vÃ¡m hostitel Å™ekne "GeÃ§" (jdi dÃ¡l), neÅ¾ vstoupÃ­te. Toto gesto ukazuje Ãºctu k domovu rodiny.
</CultureTip>

## ZÃ¡kladnÃ­ pozdravy a frÃ¡ze

| Turecky | VÃ½slovnost | ÄŒesky | Kdy pouÅ¾Ã­t |
|---------|-----------|--------|------------|
| **Merhaba** | mer-ha-ba | Ahoj | ObecnÃ½ pozdrav |
| **GÃ¼naydÄ±n** | gu-naj-dun | DobrÃ© rÃ¡no | RÃ¡no do 12:00 |
| **Ä°yi akÅŸamlar** | i-j ak-sha-lar | DobrÃ½ veÄer | Odpoledne/veÄer |
| **NasÄ±lsÄ±nÄ±z?** | na-sul-su-nuz | Jak se mÃ¡te? | FormÃ¡lnÃ­ dotaz |
| **TeÅŸekkÃ¼r ederim** | te-she-kur e-de-rim | DÄ›kuji | DÄ›kovÃ¡nÃ­ |
| **Ã–zÃ¼r dilerim** | o-zur di-le-rim | OmlouvÃ¡m se | Omluva |
| **LÃ¼tfen** | lutfen | ProsÃ­m | Å½Ã¡dost |
| **Evet/HayÄ±r** | e-vet/haj-ur | Ano/Ne | Souhlas/nesouhlas |

## Konverzace s rodinou

### S maminkou vaÅ¡eho partnera

<VocabCard
  word="YemeÄŸiniz Ã§ok lezzetli"
  translation="VaÅ¡e jÃ­dlo je velmi chutnÃ©"
  pronunciation="je-me-jiniz tchoch lez-ze-tli"
  example="Tato frÃ¡ze je klÃ­ÄovÃ¡ - tureÄtÃ­ rodiÄe vÃ¡s budou zvÃ¡t na jÃ­dlo!"
/>

**TypickÃ½ dialog:**
- **Mama:** "HoÅŸ geldiniz!" (VÃ­tejte!)
- **Vy:** "Ã‡ok teÅŸekkÃ¼r ederim, Ã§ok memnun oldum." (DÄ›kuji, tÄ›Å¡Ã­ mÄ›.)

articles.title: Expresii 'Mi-e Dor de Tine' Ã®n GermanÄƒ pentru RomÃ¢ni
articles.content:
Germanii exprimÄƒ dorul cu sinceritate È™i profunzime. DeÈ™i pot pÄƒrea rezervaÈ›i, sentimentele lor sunt autentice È™i puternice.

## Dorul Ã®n Cultura GermanÄƒ

CuvÃ¢ntul german "Sehnsucht" exprimÄƒ un dor profund, o dorinÈ›Äƒ intensÄƒ pentru ceva sau cineva. Este un concept central Ã®n romantismul german.

## Expresii EsenÈ›iale de Dor

### Expresii Directe

<Phrase>
  <Original>Ich vermisse dich so sehr.</Original>
  <Transliteration>Ih fermise dih zo zeer.</Transliteration>
  <Translation>Mi-e foarte dor de tine.</Translation>
  <Context>Cea mai directÄƒ expresie de dor.</Context>
</Phrase>

<Phrase>
  <Original>Ich kann es kaum erwarten, dich wiederzusehen.</Original>
  <Transliteration>Ih can es caum ervarten, dih viderzuzehen.</Transliteration>
  <Translation>Abia aÈ™tept sÄƒ te revÄƒd.</Translation>
  <Context>ExprimÄƒ anticiparea revederii.</Context>
</Phrase>

<Phrase>
  <Original>Ich wÃ¼nschte, du wÃ¤rst hier bei mir.</Original>
  <Transliteration>Ih vunÈ™te, du verst hir bai mir.</Transliteration>
  <Translation>Mi-aÈ™ dori sÄƒ fii aici cu mine.</Translation>
  <Context>Pentru momentele de singurÄƒtate.</Context>
</Phrase>

### Expresii Profunde

<Phrase>
  <Original>Jeder Moment ohne dich fÃ¼hlt sich wie eine Ewigkeit an.</Original>
  <Transliteration>Ieder moment one dih fult zih vi aine evihcait an.</Transliteration>
  <Translation>Fiecare moment fÄƒrÄƒ tine pare o eternitate.</Translation>
  <Context>O expresie intensÄƒ a dorului.</Context>
</Phrase>

<Phrase>
  <Original>Mein Herz gehÃ¶rt dir, egal wo du bist.</Original>
  <Transliteration>Main herÈ› ghehÃ¸rt dir, egal vo du bist.</Transliteration>
  <Translation>Inima mea Ã®È›i aparÈ›ine, indiferent unde eÈ™ti.</Translation>
  <Context>O declaraÈ›ie de fidelitate.</Context>
</Phrase>

<Phrase>
  <Original>Du bist immer in meinen Gedanken.</Original>
  <Transliteration>Du bist imer in mainen ghedanchen.</Transliteration>
  <Translation>EÈ™ti mereu Ã®n gÃ¢ndurile mele.</Translation>
  <Context>AratÄƒ cÄƒ partenerul Ã®È›i ocupÄƒ mintea.</Context>
</Phrase>

### Mesaje de DimineaÈ›Äƒ È™i SearÄƒ

<Phrase>
  <Original>Guten Morgen, Schatz. Ich bin aufgewacht und habe an dich gedacht.</Original>
  <Transliteration>Guten morghen, È™aÈ›. Ih bin aufghevacht und habe an dih ghedacht.</Transliteration>
  <Translation>BunÄƒ dimineaÈ›a, dragule. M-am trezit gÃ¢ndindu-mÄƒ la tine.</Translation>
  <Context>Mesaj de dimineaÈ›Äƒ.</Context>
</Phrase>

<Phrase>
  <Original>Gute Nacht, ich vermisse dich.</Original>
  <Transliteration>Gute naht, ih fermise dih.</Transliteration>
  <Translation>Noapte bunÄƒ, mi-e dor de tine.</Translation>
  <Context>Mesaj de noapte bunÄƒ.</Context>
</Phrase>

<Phrase>
  <Original>Ich trÃ¤ume jede Nacht von dir.</Original>
  <Transliteration>Ih troime iede naht fon dir.</Transliteration>
  <Translation>Visez la tine Ã®n fiecare noapte.</Translation>
  <Context>O expresie romanticÄƒ.</Context>
</Phrase>

### Promisiuni

<Phrase>
  <Original>Ich zÃ¤hle die Tage bis zu unserem Wiedersehen.</Original>
  <Transliteration>Ih È›ele di taghe bis È›u unzerem viderzehen.</Transliteration>
  <Translation>NumÄƒr zilele pÃ¢nÄƒ la revederea noastrÄƒ.</Translation>
  <Context>ExprimÄƒ anticiparea.</Context>
</Phrase>

<Phrase>
  <Original>Die Entfernung kann unsere Liebe nicht trennen.</Original>
  <Transliteration>Di entfernung can unzere libe niht trenen.</Transliteration>
  <Translation>DistanÈ›a nu poate separa dragostea noastrÄƒ.</Translation>
  <Context>O afirmaÈ›ie despre puterea dragostei.</Context>
</Phrase>

<Phrase>
  <Original>Bald werden wir wieder zusammen sein.</Original>
  <Transliteration>Bald verden vir vider È›uzamen zain.</Transliteration>
  <Translation>CurÃ¢nd vom fi din nou Ã®mpreunÄƒ.</Translation>
  <Context>O promisiune de reuniune.</Context>
</Phrase>

## Conceptul "Sehnsucht"

"Sehnsucht" este un cuvÃ¢nt german unic care exprimÄƒ un dor profund, o dorinÈ›Äƒ intensÄƒ È™i melancolicÄƒ. Este mai mult decÃ¢t simpla lipsÄƒ - este o dorinÈ›Äƒ existenÈ›ialÄƒ.

## Concluzie

Dorul exprimat Ã®n germanÄƒ are o sinceritate È™i profunzime aparte. Aceste expresii te vor ajuta sÄƒ comunici cu partenerul tÄƒu german È™i sÄƒ-i arÄƒÈ›i cÄƒ distanÈ›a nu poate slÄƒbi legÄƒtura voastrÄƒ!
